Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Raman and laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) microscope for interdisciplinary research and research training at Seattle University
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Christopher Stipe from Seattle University and colleagues Ryan McLaughlin, Frank Shih, Katherine Kuder and J. Wesley will acquire an integrated Raman and laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) microscope. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) identification and quantification of geological materials; (b) sediment fingerprinting in support of sediment source determination; (c) characterization of light alloys and biomaterials; (d) analysis of underground coal mining particulate matter for environmental health monitoring; and (e) development of sustainable cement-based materials.

A Raman-LIBS microscope rapidly acquires both elemental and molecular chemical information spatially across a sample surface. In Raman-mode, the instrument provides information regarding a sample's chemical composition, structure, phase, and polymorphism; in LIBS-mode, the instrument provides elemental composition. Thus chemical mapping and depth profiling of a wide array of samples can be obtained. The instrument will be used in research by faculty and students in three departments at the institution. It also will be employed in a collaborative study with the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture studying pigments used in Native American art and in a summer immersion program for STEM students from a local high school to learn chemistry and forensic science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF-MRI grant provided funds to acquire an integrated Raman and Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) microscope for the purpose of research and research training of undergraduate students at Seattle University, a small, comprehensive Jesuit-Catholic university with a commitment to faculty mentored undergraduate research in science and engineering. The two experimental techniques present in this instrument are complementary in that they provide elemental (LIBS) and molecular (Raman) information about physical systems, and are also highly general in the sense that they can be applied to a wide variety of samples. Using this instrumentation, we have endeavored to provide high-level research training and professional development opportunities to our students through the pursuit of relevant and publishable research projects.

Over the course of our project, we have involved sixteen undergraduate students in faculty-mentored research projects, producing eight conference presentations and two peer-reviewed publications. These research experiences would not have been possible without the equipment and resources made available through the NSF-MRI program. Research experiences such as those enabled by this instrument are crucial for students who wish to pursue advanced studies or laboratory positions in science and engineering fields. Several of our graduates are currently in positions such as these or will be pursuing them following their graduation from Seattle University. Furthermore, approximately half of our current and former research students are members of underrepresented groups in science and engineering. We are delighted to continue to help leverage all of our students into STEM careers as our work moves forward.

The work performed by our students and faculty members has involved advances in real-time environmental monitoring, characterization of atmospherically relevant alkyl nitrate compounds, structural studies of products formed from a new rapid source for carbon and titanium oxide solids, analysis of organic compounds present in deep-water corals as a method for potentially monitoring environmental conditions, and a variety of forensic analyses related to pollen, soil and glass samples. Through these research efforts, we have formed collaborations between the Department of Chemistry and the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Seattle University, as well as with scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA), the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), and the University of Washington Department of Mechanical Engineering. Partnerships such as these have not only provided new avenues and opportunities for our research projects, but also have exposed our students to the wider scientific community and demonstrated the benefits of working collaboratively with colleagues from diverse scientific backgrounds.

We have been able to involve students outside of our direct research endeavors with the NSF-MRI instrumentation as well via pedagogical laboratory experiences specifically designed for advanced chemistry courses. We continue to explore new opportunities for experiences such as these with interested faculty at Seattle University, and look forward to introducing more of these kinds of activities in the near future.

Overall, we view our project as a successful endeavor with a bright, sustainable future. Our faculty and their collaborators have multiple research projects currently underway and more are planned for the near future, including additional pedagogical experiences for students and additional cross-departmental collaborations. We are certainly grateful for the assistance that this funding has provided, and look forward to helping facilitate the many possibilities it has enabled for our students.
